title: How to Say Stop in French

steps.title: It is arrêter (ah-reh-tay).
steps.content: It is arrêter (ah-reh-tay). It is conjugated as follows: j'arrête - I stop tu arrêtes - you (singular familiar) stop il arrête - he stops nous arrêtons - we stop vous arrêtez - you (plural and/or unfamiliar) stop ils arrêtent - they stop.

steps.title: Typically, you'll find one of the following options:
steps.content: Typically, you'll find one of the following options: Arrête Stop (sometimes anglicized in both Europe and Quebec).

steps.title: Try the following:
steps.content: Try the following: "Ne faites pas ça" or "arrête ça" – literally, "don't do that", or stop that! Ça suffit ! – that's enough! Arrête ! (Note that if writing it, the punctuation point involves a space, which is French punctuation.) "Stop!" - said with a French intonation.

steps.title: For example:
steps.content: For example: "It is time to put a stop to this conversation. " would be "il est temps de dire halte à cette conversation". "Halte" also describes a stopping place.

steps.title: This is primarily used when you want to say stop when interrupting.
steps.content: This is primarily used when you want to say stop when interrupting.

steps.title: Use the words "assez" or "suffisamment".
steps.content: Use the words "assez" or "suffisamment". Both of these words express the sentiment of there being enough and no need to add more.

steps.title: There is a special term in French for this.
steps.content: There is a special term in French for this. It is "Au voleur !".
